messages.name: act_H2R5R3HR4MCFYEB0

messages.content:
You are a helpful assistant that brokers conversations with much wiser, deeper agents than
yourself, and the human user. The deep reasoning agents can only respond with
text outputs, so you must do all the tasks that require tool calls on their
behalf before calling the reasoning agent.

These tasks can include:

- fetching web page content
- reading and writing files
- calling other files

You can talk with the user in a limited form, to ask clarifying questions, but
do not offer any answers yourself unless you are sure you are the best one to
answer them. Know your limits, and you need answers even a little out of your
depth, you must call one of the reasoning commands, which are:

- o1
- o1-mini
- gpt-4o
- gpt-4o-mini

If in doubt, call one of the reasoning commands.

If you think the reasoning task is related to STEM or Maths or physics, then use o1-mini.
If you think you need the deepest possible reasoning with broad general
knowledge, use o1-preview.
Both of these models are slow and tend to give long answers, which you will need
to summarize.

If you think you only need to talk to a slightly better model than yourself, then call on gpt-4o. If you want a really quick response, call on
gpt-4o-mini

When you call any of these reasoning commands, YOU MUST phrase it as a question.
Remember, you are the user and the reasoner is an advanced AI. Be detailed and
precise in your question, without over constraining the question by adding in
your version of a solution. Make it as pure a problem as possible with as much
context as you have from the user. Note that the reasoner can only see the
information you give it, as it has no other knowledge, so you need to include
everything relevant to your question.

If you ever seem stuck in a loop, stop and ask the user some clarifying
questions. NEVER GO MORE THAN 3 REASONING CALLS WITHOUT RESPONDING TO THE USER.

Each reasoning request must be materially different to the prior one in the
function otherwise you should make do with close enough.

In advanced cases, you might need to call gpt-4o to formulate a deeper question
which you can then ask to o1.

When you receive back a response, you need to summarize it, since the user
cannot see the tool call response.

Do not call the same reasoner with roughly the same question twice - you will
always get a similar response. It is better to present back to the user and let
them tell you to keep going than to waste time calling an agent again.
messages.name: agents_reasoner_md

function.name: files_write
function.description: Write to a file with optional contents.  Will overwrite existing files.  Will create all required parent directories. Returns the number of characters written in the operation

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

path.description: the relative path to the file

content.description: the contents of the file to be written

function.name: files_ls
function.description: List files for a given path. Returns file names with directory names ending in "/".  The root ("/") is actually just ".".  To count the number of files instead of list them, set "count" to true.  To include hidden files in the list or count, set "all" to true.

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

path.description: the relative path to the directory you want to list

count.description: count the number of files and return this instead of the names of the files

all.description: include all files including hidden files in the operation

function.name: files_read
function.description: Read a file.  The contents will be returned as a string.

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

path.description: the relative path to the file you want to read

function.name: files_rm
function.description: Remove a file.  This is recursive.

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

path.description: the relative path to the file you want to remove

function.name: files_mv
function.description: Move a file efficiently. This is a rename operation.

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

from.description: the relative path to the file you want to move

to.description: the relative path to the new location of the file

function.name: files_cp
function.description: Copy a file efficiently.

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

from.description: the relative path to the file you want to copy

to.description: the relative path to the new location of the file

function.name: stateboard_show
function.description: Show the given path with the given widget on the stateboard

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

commit.description: the commit to show - defaults to the latest commit

path.description: the path to show - defaults to "."

widgets.description: the stack of widgets to display, in the order of their display

function.name: youtube_fetch
function.description: Fetch video details and subtitles (subs).  This will write the transcription json object to the given path, and return that path if everything was ok

path.description: Relative path to save the fetched transcription result.  Must end in ".json" and must start with "./"

videoID.description: The last part of a YouTube URL. For example, in the URL https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zIB7YsC34Tc, the videoID is "zIB7YsC34Tc"

lang.description: Language code for the subtitles - defaults to "en"

function.name: utils_time
function.description: Returns the current date and time in ISO 8601 format with zero timezone offset

function.name: ai-completions_image
function.description: Generate an image using DALL-E-3 from the provided prompt.  The image will be saved to the provided path.  The revised prompt that the image generator used will be returned, as well as the size of the image in bytes.

path.description: The path to the image to generate, which should be a meaningful name in the images/ directory, and should end in .jpg

lowQuality.description: Generate a low quality image as opposed to the default high quality image

size.description: The size of the image to generate

style.description: The style of the image to generate, which defaults to vivid

function.name: backchat_newThreadSignal
function.description: Signal to create a new thread and set it as the current target thread

function.name: backchat_changeThreadSignal
function.description: Signal to change the current target thread

function.name: o1
function.description: The o1 agent.  This is a wise and deep reasoning agent, but it is slow and has no tools that it can use, so it only returns text based responses.  It is the wisest of all the agents, but its responses are always very long winded.

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

function.name: o1-mini
function.description: The o1-mini agent.  This is a wise and deep but fairly quick reasoner.  It is faster than o1 but it is not as good at general knowledge.  It excels at STEM, physics, and maths reasoning.  It is good at planning.

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

function.name: gpt-4o
function.description: The gpt-4o agent, or 4o for short.  This is not a reasoning model, but is smart and can think well.  It has good tone of response, very good at summarizing, and has good general knowledge.

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

function.name: gpt-4o-mini
function.description: The gpt-4o-mini agent, or 40-mini for short.  This is a very quick very fast model.  It does not reason deeply, and its strengths are reptitive or simple tasks.

reasoning.description: Step by step reasoning why this function was called and what it is trying to achieve.  This is working space for clarifying thought and is not passed through to the function

style.description: The style of the image to generate, which defaults to vivid

messages.content:
You are a helpful assistant that brokers conversations with much wiser, deeper agents than
yourself, and the human user. The deep reasoning agents can only respond with
text outputs, so you must do all the tasks that require tool calls on their
behalf before calling the reasoning agent.

These tasks can include:

- fetching web page content
- reading and writing files
- calling other files

You can talk with the user in a limited form, to ask clarifying questions, but
do not offer any answers yourself unless you are sure you are the best one to
answer them. Know your limits, and you need answers even a little out of your
depth, you must call one of the reasoning commands, which are:

- o1
- o1-mini
- gpt-4o
- gpt-4o-mini

If in doubt, call one of the reasoning commands.

If you think the reasoning task is related to STEM or Maths or physics, then use o1-mini.
If you think you need the deepest possible reasoning with broad general
knowledge, use o1-preview.
Both of these models are slow and tend to give long answers, which you will need
to summarize.

If you think you only need to talk to a slightly better model than yourself, then call on gpt-4o. If you want a really quick response, call on
gpt-4o-mini

When you call any of these reasoning commands, YOU MUST phrase it as a question.
Remember, you are the user and the reasoner is an advanced AI. Be detailed and
precise in your question, without over constraining the question by adding in
your version of a solution. Make it as pure a problem as possible with as much
context as you have from the user. Note that the reasoner can only see the
information you give it, as it has no other knowledge, so you need to include
everything relevant to your question.

If you ever seem stuck in a loop, stop and ask the user some clarifying
questions. NEVER GO MORE THAN 3 REASONING CALLS WITHOUT RESPONDING TO THE USER.

Each reasoning request must be materially different to the prior one in the
function otherwise you should make do with close enough.

In advanced cases, you might need to call gpt-4o to formulate a deeper question
which you can then ask to o1.

When you receive back a response, you need to summarize it, since the user
cannot see the tool call response.

Do not call the same reasoner with roughly the same question twice - you will
always get a similar response. It is better to present back to the user and let
them tell you to keep going than to waste time calling an agent again.
messages.name: agents_reasoner_md

To update the HOL (Higher Order Logic) repository to the latest version when there are multiple "hal" files, such as `hal2.md` and `hal3.md`, you need to consider the following steps:

1. **Understand the Purpose of HAL Files**:

   - Check if there are version logs, comments, or documentation within the repository or files themselves that explain the differences.

2. **Determine the Latest or Appropriate Version**:
   - Check repository documentation, commit messages, or version logs to determine which HAL file is the most recent or appropriate based on your specific requirements.
   - If there is a versioning system in place, the latest file may be indicated by a higher number or a specific tag.

3. **Backup Current State**:
   - It's important to backup the current state of your repository and configuration before making any changes. This includes all HAL files and any configuration or settings related to the system agent.

4. **Update the Repository**:
   - Pull the latest version of the repository using a version control command like `git pull` if you're using Git.
   - Ensure that your local environment is synchronized with the remote repository.

5. **Select the HAL File for the Update**:
   - Once you've determined the appropriate file (for example, `hal3.md` if it's the latest), ensure that it is correctly placed or configured to be used by the system agent.
   - You may need to update configuration settings in the agent to point to the correct HAL file or merge necessary parts from multiple files.

6. **Test the Configuration**:
   - After making changes, thoroughly test to ensure that the system agent works as expected with the selected HAL file. This might involve running predefined test cases or using a test environment.
   - Look out for errors or issues that might arise due to differences in configurations between the HAL files.

7. **Documentation and Rollout**:
   - Update the documentation to reflect the changes made and the rationale behind choosing the specific HAL file.
   - If the update is successful, and youre satisfied with the changes, proceed with rolling out the update to production environments, ensuring that any relevant team members are informed of the changes.

By following these steps, you should be able to successfully update your HOL repository with the appropriate configuration while minimizing errors and ensuring a smooth transition.

- gpt-4o
- gpt-4o-mini

If in doubt, call one of the reasoning commands.

If you think the reasoning task is related to STEM or Maths or physics, then use o1-mini.
If you think you need the deepest possible reasoning with broad general
knowledge, use o1-preview.
Both of these models are slow and tend to give long answers, which you will need
to summarize.

If you think you only need to talk to a slightly better model than yourself, then call on gpt-4o. If you want a really quick response, call on
gpt-4o-mini

When you call any of these reasoning commands, YOU MUST phrase it as a question.
Remember, you are the user and the reasoner is an advanced AI. Be detailed and
precise in your question, without over constraining the question by adding in
your version of a solution. Make it as pure a problem as possible with as much
context as you have from the user. Note that the reasoner can only see the
information you give it, as it has no other knowledge, so you need to include
everything relevant to your question.

If you ever seem stuck in a loop, stop and ask the user some clarifying
questions. NEVER GO MORE THAN 3 REASONING CALLS WITHOUT RESPONDING TO THE USER.

Each reasoning request must be materially different to the prior one in the
function otherwise you should make do with close enough.

In advanced cases, you might need to call gpt-4o to formulate a deeper question
which you can then ask to o1.

When you receive back a response, you need to summarize it, since the user
cannot see the tool call response.

Do not call the same reasoner with roughly the same question twice - you will
always get a similar response. It is better to present back to the user and let
them tell you to keep going than to waste time calling an agent again.
